title: Troll bullied me out of my lane
body:
Yes, it´s a rant.

Here it is:

I was first pick on solo queue and after seing the enemy 1st pick locking heimer i decided to counter him with a morgana mid.

I CLEARLY stated that i was going  mid. So the second pick called top and decided to go with talon.

Our team last pick didn´t go with a jungler, which was the last role available, but went with xerath instead. I only saw this after the loading started (i´m to blame). And i thought: "no biggie, we can still do fine".

Then came this talon out of the blue, claiming he "called mid" in a ranked match. Now if he´d asked nicely, i could let him mid. But he went like: "stfu your fault you took a support mid". Even though i told EVERYONE i was going morg mid.

At this point i already know it´s a lost match, since i´m already behind on farm, i´m pissed and i won´t perform like i would in a normal situation.

So i have three choices: 

1- stay mid with him and we both get underfarmed. He will still somehow manage to get the support of the rest of the team and i WILL be reported for not going to another lane.

2- Back down, accept the abuse, join another lane, perform poorly (see above) and get reported anyway.

3 - Open /all , say something like " I´m sorry everyone, there´s a troll on my team and i won´t be abused." Then DC right away and go do something else. Oh, and i will probably be reported for Leaving/AFK.

Usually i go with option 3, just cause i know i´ll have no fun, and i just can´t stand trolls getting away with the things they do. Yea, i know the rest of the team is going to suffer because of this, but for me is still the best option.

Usually, after trolling and abusing ppl like that, the trolls will generally try and throw the rest of the team against you. Funny enough, they always succeed.

I mean, the whole team saw that i was abused, trolled and bullied out of my lane and somehow i´m the bad guy all of a sudden? And the troll will get away with what he wants. This is not an isolated case, every troll i come by will do the same thing, and i will still be reported.

What´s the problem with you people?

TL;DR : i get trolled AND reported. The troll gets away with it.

replies.body: I've had this happen many times actually(I don't AFK though), and it is very odd that people usually side with the troll. Your best choice in these situations is to continue playing, try and share CS, and try to win. You're 2v1, so push the lane, take tower, roam, etc. 2 mid means 2 trinkets, so you should really never get ganked.
Chance are, if someone is unintelligent enough to troll, they are NOT going to trinket, roam, or do anything to help you win.

actually you have to consider what you can be reported for.

If you don't say anything, and find a way to try to contribute  (change lanes, go farm jungle, become a roaming support/ganker) its hard to report you for anything.

You didn't intentionally feed
You didn't use offensive language
You didn't verbally abuse anyone
You showed that you don't have a negative attitude
You showed that you weren't unskilled.
As long as you ping, you didn't "failed to communicate"

The only claim that would be remotely possible would be "aiding enemy team" and that is something that the logs would show you didn't do.

Believe me I've had this happen once.

I had just finished a game where I started as jungle Elise, but our support AFKed and the ADC begged me to come support.  It was only my second game on Elise, and I couldn't do much, so after the ADC berated me I apologized once and just tried to do my best.  It was a frustrating match we lost quickly.

However, right after that I entered another lobby and ran into the ADC again.  This time they took Brand and said they'd go mid, while I took Zyra to support.  Only for the game to start and I see Brand march down the river to bot lane.  And stay!   I grumbled once and then moved to mid-lane where I struggled as I had masteries and items for support.  (this was pre-level 20 for me.)  After the game the Brand did report me, but since then I know of no other report against me for any similar activity.  

The key is to avoid arguing with the troll.  You won't win.  Just move on quickly.
Sounds very similar to something my dad always used to tell me. "Never argue with an idiot. They'll just drag you down to their level and beat you with experience."
so true, and I've found trolls are the same way.

 And since i was out of my lane, against a way stronger oponent, i was like 1/2/0, then 1/3/1 and my team started to agree with him and by the end of the game they all agreed to report me.

ITS NOT YOUR JOB TO CHANGE A TROLLISH PLAYER!

I think that's your biggest issue.  You seem to think that you are somehow supposed to change the troll, but its not.  I've been in a position where that was a duty I volunteered for and I learned quickly how to deal with trolls, and trust me arguing with one never works.  You can't engage with them, especially while they are already angry.  And since Riot's punishments take time to show up, trolls and their victims often think nothing is happening.

----

As for surrender timers.  Riot isn't going to make it so 3 players can pass a vote.  They already have people demanding that surrender be removed from ranked play, so they won't make it easier to surrender.  I agree it can be frustrating to be in a match you know is unwinnable and have 2 people who refuse to vote for the surrender, but that's going to happen.  There are a lot of people playing LoL who have a "Never give up, Never Surrender!" attitude.  All you can do is play the game out when they refuse to surrender.

You have to decide what your priority is: Winning, or punishing the troll?
If winning is your #1 priority, it's simple (and boring): be as nice as you possibly can. "Sorry man, I misunderstood. You take mid, I'll sup. It'd be great if you could roam a bit, too.". Say nothing if he does bad, and "sorry, doing my best" if anyone bm's you. Humble pie.

If punishing the troll is your #1 priority, it becomes more fun and interesting: It is now time to become a successful **COUNTERTROLL**

Your objective: Make sure the troll gets the *exact opposite* of what he wants from this game.
In this game, we can see the troll wants either to A) play his favorite role and enjoy himself or, failing that, he wants to B) cause a scene and make you mad. You must make sure he does neither.

Obviously, you first must deny his primary objective for trolling: He doesn't get to solo mid. Get mid items, and go mid. Make one very calm comment, such as "Sorry guys, as first pick I'm going to insist on taking the lane I called". That is the ONLY time you should acknowledge the situation. Ignore any arguments from other team members.

Now he will move to plan B, in which he tries to make you mad by A) disrupting your usual play, B) verbally harassing you, C) turning other players against you and D) possibly intentionally causing a loss. You must thwart tactics when you can, and defeat their overall intent to make you mad.

This means do NOT acknowledge him, or his trolling, at all. Countertroll "don'ts" include:

**DON'T** say "report X". No matter how much you want to "set the record straight" DON'T do it. It will start the "No, report Y!" frenzy. This makes you look petty, it gets both teams ranting about who to report, it muddies the water and makes it unclear who really started it.

**DON'T** appear overly invested in the outcome of the game. Appear calm at all times, as if you're just having fun. This means avoid any comments like "OMG!", "WTF?", or spamming pings. It means not placing blame on anyone, nor discuss if your team is winning or losing. Do not say "we need to", or use all caps. Do not say "gg" early or "FF at 20". 

**DON'T** reference how the trolls actions make your game suffer. No comments like "Normally I'm better at...". No acknowledgement of negative feelings that could make the troll feel empowered.

Now for some DO's:

**DO** ignore the troll completely. Don't say anything to him. Put him on mute, or make damn sure you NEVER respond to a comment of his. Don't remark when he dies or makes a mistake, since he'll do the same to you if you fail later. Don't BM him, as it will make you look bad to other players. Remain COMPLETELY UNAFFECTED by anything he says.

**DO** make positive comments to team mates, and good-natured banter with the other team. It will get the other players on your side. They will see you are  a friendly, level-headed person, and the trolls badmouth and requests to report you will be held against him. This positive attitude will also show the troll he's failing to ruin your experience.

**DO** try to secretly ruin his game. Steal his CS and/or kills, take any buff he's trying to get, lure into fights then leave him to die. DON'T MAKE IT OBVIOUS. You want ONLY the troll to know your doing this. This will make him rage against you, and lower his score, making him appear to be the toxic one. Don't try too hard! Don't waste big spells or flashes on KSing or buff stealing. It will make him happy if you fail, and the other players might notice what you're doing.

If you do everything right, the following will happen:

The troll will have an awful game, and no satisfaction from trolling. He didn't get to play the role he wanted, the person he tried to make mad never even acknowledged him had fun anyway, and everybody else in the game is pissed at him and reporting him. The next time he thinks about troll-picking, he will remember this feeling of defeat and reconsider. You win.

Your teammate who intentionally DC'd might try to use the excuse "I was being bullied", but for me that is no excuse.  It's an explanation, but that counts for little.

The problem here is that you entered the game knowing there was a chance that you'd run into an emotional and angry person with no morals who sees nothing wrong with abusing other players.  And this isn't unique to LoL.  Its an endemic problem on the internet.   I remember when blogging was just getting started and many people joked that it was angry young men living in their parent's basements and wearing pajamas doing it.

Now those angry young men are just playing video games.

I can bet that if I asked around in the most popular 10 or so MMO's/online games I'd find that there are trolls in all of them, and no matter what method is used by the company to try to control them, they do manage to break out and cause trouble.  My girlfriend plays games on her tablet and says that they are endemic in most of the games she's tried.  I've run into them in every MMORPG I've played and even in one MMORPG became a volunteer who tried to control the behavior with visible punishments and a clear demarcation line where a certain number of incidents got the account banned/deleted.  And that didn't work because trolls would just create throwaway accounts to troll from.

YOu have to realize that by DCing you allow the troll to "win".  He can feel like he's a big dog because he chased someone from the game.

If you argue with him, he's got a good chance of turning people against you, (you escalated the incident) again, he wins.

That's why you have to be passive against an internet bully.  no one likes the bully, but they often can hide behind the reaction if the reaction causes more harm.  You just can't react like you would in a classroom or work environment.

-----

My other recommendation is that you have to have a thick skin towards abuse on the internet.  Remember that the troll doesn't know you, what you look like, where you live or anything.  He's using you as a proxy for all the bullies at his high school who kicked dirt in his face and threw him in the trashcan in front of the senior class during his freshman year.  You are a proxy for every girl who laughed at him when he tried to talk to her.  For the coworker who was promoted faster than him, and for every failure he's ever suffered.  You can't "win" against that by fighting it.  At best you can ignore it and it will quickly wash away.  No one will remember.  I can guarantee you that the rager probably won't remember your username the next day.  He's not focused on you, but on the anger.

Yes, they shouldn't be playing a competitive game, but that's for Riot to act on.  For you, ignore, finish the game, report and move on.  The fact that you keep playing "yes but," with me shows that you allows the troll to win.  You are obsessing over it to the point that I'd almost recommend that you never play LoL again.  You need to be able to deal with this kind of situation without allowing it to rule your life.  Trust me you'll run into similar situations for the rest of your life.
